title: Budget 2015: Banks hit by £1.6bn tax hike
text:
257.30 +5.15 
The bank levy is being cut back, but this will be more than offset by an additional tax on profits 
Britain’s banks will pay an extra £1.6bn to the Treasury over the next five years under new plans to introduce a special tax on their profits. 
The bank levy, a charge on banks’ global balance sheets, will be cut in half over the rest of this parliament, Chancellor George Osborne announced in his emergency Budget . 
However, it will be replaced by an 8pc tax on annual profits, on top of the corporation tax that lenders already pay. 
“It means we’ll actually raise more from the banks this parliament, but at the same time make our country a more competitive place to do business,” said Mr Osborne. 
At the same time, the changes mean that banks with more UK-focused business, such as Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) and Lloyds, as well as small challenger banks, will be worse off over the long-term, while banks with large international arms, such as HSBC, which is the biggest payer of the levy, will see its financial burden slowly eased. 
Lenders had been lobbying for a cut to the levy, arguing that it has cost the UK thousands of jobs by encouraging foreign banks to hire workers overseas and base them abroad to avoid the levy, rather than taking on British employees. 
But the news in Wednesday's Budget was met with disappointment from the banking industry. 
“Introducing yet another new bank-specific tax will reinforce fears that Britain is becoming a less attractive place for banks to do business,” said Anthony Browne, chief of the British Bankers’ Association. 
“This is the fifth new bank-specific tax measure in as many years, following fast on the heels of the big rise in March and will increase banks’ tax burden by nearly £2bn. We believe these moves will also undermine competition in the industry by making it harder for smaller players to break through and challenge larger banks.” 
Mr Osborne introduced the bank levy in 2010. Since then, he has raised it nine times , from the original level of 0.05pc to its current 0.21pc. 
Under the latest plans, the levy will be cut to 0.18pc next year, before falling gradually to 0.1pc in 2020, at which point it will be restricted to UK assets. 
HSBC and Standard Chartered (HKSE: 2888.HK - news ) have major global units affected by the bank levy, which has made it harder for them to compete with foreign-based banks operating in the same countries. As a result, both lenders have discussed moving their headquarters out of the UK . 
The levy changes offer some reprieve to those big international banks, but will not be as big a help for those with a focus on the UK. 
Analyst Chirantan Barua, from Bernstein Research, expects Barclays to be the hardest hit of the big banks. And he does not expect HSBC to be satisfied by the changes. 
“For HSBC, there was no positive news to be had from this budget. 2021 is too long a duration for a political promise to base your strategic domicile on. The pressure to relocate has actually increased today,” Mr Barua said. 
Moreover, the new 8pc tax will be levied on banks with profits above £25m and is expected to affect roughly 200 lenders. By contrast, the bank levy applied to around 30 banks. 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in challenger banks fell sharply on Mr Osborne's announcement. Virgin Money’s shares tumbled 10pc, Aldermore’s dived 12.2pc and Shawbrook Bank’s stock slid 9.6pc. 
The 8pc tax will also be a headache for banks which have made big losses in recent years, because it will not allow them to bring forward those losses to offset the tax burden. 
Historically, if a bank made a loss one year, but a profit of the same size the following year, it would pay no corporation tax over the two-year period. In March, the Chancellor cut that relief in half. 
“Eight months ago a bank which made losses last year may have thought it had no tax to pay in 2016. Since then they’ve seen that rate go up to 10pc and now 18pc,” said Deloitte’s Wayne Weaver.
